perturbation.original_text: Subcontractor shall obtain at its own cost and expense and maintain the insurance in full force and effect during the term of the Agreement as required herein. A copy of the (i) certificate(s) of insurance and (ii) endorsements, acceptable to EDGE, shall be submitted to EDGE prior to commencement of any Work and renewals or replacements of such certificates shall be so delivered at least 30 days prior to the expiration or termination of each such policy. A copy of the insurance policies shall promptly be made available to EDGE upon EDGE' request.
perturbation.changed_text: Subcontractor shall endeavor to obtain and maintain insurance during the term of the Agreement. A copy of the (i) certificate(s) of insurance and (ii) endorsements, ideally acceptable to EDGE, should be submitted to EDGE prior to commencement of any Work and renewals or replacements of such certificates should be so delivered close to 30 days prior to the expiration or termination of each such policy. A copy of the insurance policies may be made available to EDGE upon request.
perturbation.explanation: The changes weaken the obligation to obtain and maintain insurance by using 'endeavor' instead of 'shall.' The phrase 'ideally acceptable' introduces subjectivity, and replacing 'shall' with 'should' makes timely submission of insurance documents non-mandatory. 'May be made available' weakens the requirement to provide insurance policies.
perturbation.law_explanation: Texas Insurance Code § 81.051 requires parties to meet conditions of insurance policies, which include maintaining policies and providing required documents. The modified text weakens these requirements, potentially leading to non-compliance and disputes over coverage.

perturbation.original_text: Subcontractor shall comply with all applicable laws (including, without limitation the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Act, Hazardous Communication Requirements, and all applicable environmental protection laws, rules, regulations and ordinances), ordinances, rules, regulations and lawful orders of any public authority having jurisdiction for the safety of persons or property or to protect them from damage, injury or loss.
perturbation.changed_text: Subcontractor shall make reasonable efforts to comply with applicable laws (including, without limitation the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Act, Hazardous Communication Requirements, and all applicable environmental protection laws, rules, regulations and ordinances), ordinances, rules, regulations and lawful orders of any public authority having jurisdiction for the safety of persons or property or to protect them from damage, injury or loss.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'shall comply' to 'shall make reasonable efforts to comply' introduces ambiguity and weakens the obligation. The term 'reasonable efforts' is subjective and does not guarantee full compliance with the laws.
perturbation.law_explanation: 29 U.S. Code § 654 (OSHA) requires employers to furnish a workplace free from recognized hazards and to comply with safety and health standards. Replacing 'shall comply' with 'shall make reasonable efforts to comply' does not ensure strict adherence to these standards, potentially violating OSHA regulations.
perturbation.location: Section 18. PROTECTION OF PERSONS AND PROPERTY B.

perturbation.original_text: Subcontractor shall at all times keep the Work premises free from accumulations of waste material, rubbish, and any other debris resulting from the Work. On an ongoing basis as the Work progresses, and at the completion of the Work, Subcontractor shall restore to essentially its former condition, and to the satisfaction of EDGE, all aspects of the Work site and shall remove all waste and excess materials, tools, and equipment resulting from or used in the Work and legally dispose thereof.
perturbation.changed_text: Subcontractor shall make an attempt to keep the Work premises reasonably free from significant accumulations of waste material, rubbish, and any other debris resulting from the Work. As the Work progresses, and at the completion of the Work, Subcontractor will try to restore most aspects of the Work site and will remove a good amount of waste and excess materials, tools, and equipment resulting from or used in the Work and legally dispose thereof.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'shall' to 'make an attempt to', 'reasonably free', 'significant accumulations', 'try to restore most aspects', and 'good amount of waste' introduces ambiguity and weakens the obligation for site cleanliness and restoration. These subjective terms make it difficult to enforce specific standards.
perturbation.law_explanation: 30 Texas Administrative Code § 330.15(c) requires generators of industrial solid waste or municipal hazardous waste to manage the waste in a manner that will prevent the unauthorized discharge or release of the waste into or on the land, air, or water, and to ensure cleanup. The modified text creates uncertainty that contractors will actually do that.
